utterance_text: Hi, Sal. Thanks for taking the time to be here today.
No problem.
I noticed your doctor referred you and appreciate you making the effort to come in.
It's a bit of an inconvenience, but I'm here now.
Can you share what you understand about why your doctor suggested this appointment?
Something about changing my life more. They want me to cut down drinking, smoking, even get rid of Oscar, my dog. It's all overwhelming.
It sounds like there's a lot going on, Sal. Your asthma, stress, and these lifestyle changes.
Yeah, it feels like everything's spiraling.
We have about 15-20 minutes together. Let's take a moment to list what's happening for you. Which would you find most helpful to focus on?
Everything feels chaotic, but I guess we should start somewhere.
We'll use an agenda-setting worksheet to organize thoughts. Nothing has to change just yet; it's about understanding your situation better.
Okay, as long as I'm not committing to anything.
Great. Let's list what others suggest you change or work on. Your asthma is one?
Yes, and they want me to give up Oscar, my dog. That's stressful; he's been with me longer than my wife.
It must be upsetting to consider giving up your dog.
Yeah, it's a big stressor. And I'm trying to cut down smoking too.
So, asthma, dog, and smoking are high on your list?
Yes, and money's tight with my wife on maternity leave. Appointments take time off work too.
Those are interconnected issues, Sal.
Yeah, it's all connected somehow.
If you could pick two top priorities for today, what would they be?
The thoughts about Oscar and managing my asthma better.
Okay. Those seem related. Let's start with those.
It sounds like your wife has been encouraging you to focus on your health lately, and it seems this has been causing some tension between you two. Can you tell me more about that?

Yeah, well, she's always on my case about improving my habits, but I don't really see what the issue is. I work hard all day, sometimes I can't make it home for dinner, so I grab a bite at places like Applebee's. It's not a big deal, right?
I see. So, you feel that your current lifestyle isn't negatively impacting your health in any way?
That's right. I mean, my job is physically demanding, and I'm sweating out all the bad stuff anyway.
Have you noticed any changes in your weight or how your clothes fit recently?
A little bit, but nothing too significant. I'm not feeling bloated or anything.
I see. When was the last time you had a check-up with your doctor?
Last year for my annual physical. Everything checked out fine then.
That's good to know. It sounds like you feel confident in your current health status, but your wife might have some valid concerns as well?
Yeah, I know she just wants what's best for me, but sometimes it feels like she's overreacting. After a long day at work, it's nice to treat myself once in a while.
I understand. Would you be open to learning more about the potential risks associated with obesity and diabetes, so you can make informed decisions about your health?
Sure, that sounds helpful.
Sarah, I'm really glad you could make it for your well-woman exam today. We've covered a lot of ground, and now I'd like to explore more about your smoking habits, if that's okay with you?
Yeah, sure.
Great. Could you tell me roughly how many cigarettes you smoke in a day? You mentioned it had increased recently.
Yeah, so like once in the morning, once during lunch, and then maybe five or six in the evenings.
I see. So about eight cigarettes daily, which is just under half a pack. When did this increase start?
Um, over the past year, I guess. It's been more in the evenings since my son goes to bed.
I understand. That time of day can be stressful with your busy schedule. You mentioned you work full-time and are also taking night classes.
Yeah, it's a lot. I just need that time to unwind.
Of course. Apart from smoking, do you have other ways to relax in the evenings?
Sometimes I'll have a drink or two.
I see. On average, how many drinks would you say you have daily and weekly?
Maybe two max daily. But why does this matter? I'm here for my regular check-up, not to discuss my drinking habits.

Sarah, I understand your concern. My role is to provide information and listen to your thoughts without judgment. We want to ensure you're aware of all health resources available to you, including those related to smoking and alcohol consumption.
Okay, fine.

Great. Let's talk about the health risks associated with increased smoking and alcohol use. These include various cancers like colon, cervical, breast, lung, and pancreatic, as well as liver disease, heart disease, diabetes, and hypertension.
Wow, I didn't realize it was that serious.
It can be. But remember, we're here to discuss your thoughts and goals. On a scale of 0-10, how ready are you to quit smoking?
Um, maybe a five? I'm not fully ready yet.
That's okay. What makes it a five rather than a four for you?
Well, you mentioned the cancer risks and being a mother... It's scary.
I understand. Given these health concerns and your goals, where do you see yourself in considering change? What steps could move you closer to a 10 on that readiness scale?
Maybe cutting back in the evenings? Like smoking three instead of five or six?
That's a significant reduction. Let's meet again in four weeks to review this plan and your lab results, okay?
Yeah, sure.
Great. I have some helpful resources on smoking cessation here. Would you like them?
Yes, please.
Also, would you consider speaking with Dr. Kirtley about stress management and alcohol use? He's an expert in this area.
Maybe just the stress part for now. I'm not sure about discussing my drinking habits.
Understood. We'll schedule both appointments before you leave today. Any other questions, Sarah?
Nope.
It was nice meeting you. See you in a month.
Welcome. How can I assist you today?

Hi, I hope you can help me. My workplace just went smoke-free and... I'm not thrilled about it. I still want to keep smoking, but I was wondering if there's anything that could help me cope with the day-to-day changes.
I see. Your workplace has become smoke-free, and this change is causing some distress for you. You're not ready to quit smoking just yet, but you're looking for ways to manage the transition.
Yeah, exactly. I mean, I've been smoking for about five years now, and it's a part of my routine. I don't want to give it up, but I'm curious about what options I have.
Let's explore that together. Can you tell me more about how smoking fits into your daily life?
Well, I smoke less than a pack a day, mostly on breaks at work, in the mornings, and after work. It helps me relax. But I don't want to quit just yet.
So smoking is currently an important part of your life, and you're not ready to change that, but if you did decide to quit someday, you feel confident about your ability to do so.
Yes, that's right. I could quit if I wanted to, but I don't want to just yet.
I understand. On a scale of 1 to 10, where 1 is not considering quitting at all and 10 is ready to quit, where would you place yourself?
Probably a two. I haven't really thought about quitting until today, but now that it's on my mind, maybe I could be convinced.
It sounds like you're open to the idea of change, even if it's not your immediate goal. There are indeed products available that can help curb nicotine cravings and manage withdrawal symptoms.
That's good to know. I'm not ready to do anything today, but it's helpful to have options if I ever decide to quit.
Absolutely. Now, what might make you more open to the idea of quitting in the future? You mentioned earlier that you're a two on the readiness scale. What could move you up to a four or five?
I guess if one of my friends decided to quit with me, that would help. But none of them are planning to quit anytime soon.
It's possible that some of your coworkers might be considering quitting now that the workplace is smoke-free. That could provide some social support for you as well.
You're right, I hadn't thought about that. Thanks for bringing it up.
Of course. Today seems to be more about gathering information for you. When you're ready to explore products or strategies further, just let me know.
Okay, thank you. I appreciate your help today.
Hi, Laura. Welcome.
Hi.

Thanks for joining me today. Let's briefly discuss what we'll be doing here. I'm here to understand your goals and aspirations better, explore some behaviors you might engage in, and see how I can support you. It's not my role to judge or change you; I'm here to listen and help you navigate your life.
Okay.
Let's start by you telling me a bit about yourself.
Hi, I'm Laura, 17 years old, senior in high school. I hope to go to college and study pre-law.
That sounds like an exciting plan. What do you enjoy doing for fun?
On weekends, I hang out with friends, sometimes at parties or social events. I don't drink much, maybe one or two drinks max.
I see. How does alcohol fit into your social scene?
Well, I might have a drink to blend in, but I'm not really interested in getting drunk. I've seen others have negative experiences with it.
I understand. It sounds like you're being mindful about your drinking.
How important is it for you to make adjustments to your drinking habits?
On a scale of 1-10, maybe a 5 or 6. It's not something I think about constantly, but I'm aware of it.
Got it. And how confident are you that you could make changes if you wanted to?
An 8 or 9 out of 10. I don't drink much now, so it wouldn't be difficult for me to stop.
That's great to hear. Let's set a goal for today. How about trying not to drink at the next party you attend?
Sure, that sounds doable.
What benefits do you see from following through with this goal?
I'll have all my senses and be aware of everything happening. Plus, it's healthier for me.
Those are excellent points. Let's meet again in a few weeks to check in on how it goes. Sound good?
Yes, that works.
Great. Is there anything else you'd like to discuss or any questions you have?
No, I'm good for now.
All right then. Thanks for coming in today, Laura. Let's stay in touch.
Thank you. Bye.
Good morning, Barbara Roberts?
Yes, good morning.
Hello, I'm Dr. Betty, one of the new GPs here. To start, could you please tell me how you'd like me to address you?
Please call me Barbara, thank you.
Thank you, Barbara. I understand that Dr. Brown is usually your GP. Could you tell me why you've come to see me today?
Well, I've been having terrible stomach problems for some time now. Dr. Brown hasn't been able to get to the bottom of it, so I thought perhaps you could help.
I see. Can you share more about these stomach issues you're experiencing?
Yes, I have constant discomfort, bloating, alternating constipation and diarrhea, cramping, stabbing pains, and I pass very smelly wind often.
That sounds quite troublesome, Barbara. How long have you been dealing with these symptoms?
It started about four years ago after a holiday in Egypt where I had severe diarrhea. My stomach hasn't been right since then.
I see. And what treatments have you tried so far for these symptoms?
Dr. Brown prescribed muscle relaxants initially, but I've also tried various herbal remedies from the health shop. I always carry Imodium with me too.
I understand. Now, Barbara, how are these stomach problems affecting your daily life?

It's had a big impact. I went from full-time to part-time work due to discomfort, and eventually, I had to stop working altogether about a year ago. I also stopped going to exercise classes and socializing with friends as much.
That sounds like quite a significant change in your lifestyle. Have there been any times when your symptoms improved or felt better?
Last summer, my son got married, and surprisingly, my stomach was fine during that time. But generally, I've noticed my symptoms worsen when my husband is away for work.
That's interesting to note. Now, Barbara, what do you think might be causing your stomach problems? Have you had any thoughts about this?
Sometimes I worry it could be an infection that hasn't cleared up or maybe IBS. Other times, I fear it might be something more serious like cancer.

It's understandable that you're concerned about these possibilities. But based on what we know so far, do you think there might be a connection between your symptoms and how you're feeling emotionally or the changes in your lifestyle?
I don't see how my mind could cause this much pain.

I'm not suggesting the pain is all in your mind, Barbara. But sometimes physical symptoms can be influenced by our emotions and life circumstances. Would you be open to exploring this idea further over the next few months?
That sounds like a long time if there's something seriously wrong.

I understand your concern, but if we work together regularly, we can monitor your symptoms closely. If they change or worsen, we'll investigate further. But if they stay the same, it will give us reassurance that nothing new is developing.
Okay, so you're saying I should come back and see you next week to discuss this further?
Yes, that would be a good start. We can book a double slot for next week, and please bring or make a list of all the tablets you're currently taking. This will help us review them together.
All right, I'll make an appointment for next week and bring my tablet list.
Thank you, Barbara. Until then, take care.
You too. Bye-bye.
I hear that your asthma symptoms have been quite challenging lately. Let's explore some ways to improve your health and prevent future hospital visits.
Yeah, I definitely don't want to come back here again. But my doctor mentioned Oscar, my dog, might be connected to my symptoms. It's just so sudden after 12 years together.
That must feel quite unexpected. You're aware of the clinic materials about managing asthma and pets being a common trigger, right?
Yes, I have them and I've read them. But I've been focusing on taking my medication. I'm not as knowledgeable about other aspects.

I see. Given your concern for your baby's health and your progress in quitting smoking, it's crucial to address this pet issue now. It might be hard, but there are always alternatives like adoption by friends or family.
This feels overwhelming right now. John Carlo isn't affected by Oscar. It's just me. I don't want to rush into decisions without understanding the root cause better.
Your health is my primary concern, Sal. You've had several severe asthma attacks. Adults with severe asthma can face life-threatening risks. We must take this seriously.
So, suddenly Oscar could kill me? He's been with me for 12 years without issue. The doctor mentioned stress and finances too. Why focus solely on Oscar?
Your asthma is progressively worsening, Sal. Medication alone might not be enough soon. If Oscar is that important, do you prioritize him over your baby and wife? Let's find a solution together.
I understand, but you don't grasp my situation fully. I've had Oscar for 12 years. I'm not ready to rehome him without solid evidence he's the main trigger.
Alright, let's then consider other factors too and find a balanced approach that respects your attachment to Oscar while prioritizing your health.
Alright, David. Let's start by taking a moment to check in with yourself. How are you feeling today?
Pretty good, actually.
I'm glad to hear that. Would you like to take a look at something together? What do you think about this?
Oh, that looks great! You really took care of that discoloration issue.
I'm pleased with the result too. It seems there was quite a bit of staining present. Have you given any thought to what might be contributing to that?
Hmm, well, the usual suspects - smoking, wine, coffee. All guilty as charged.
I see. Have you considered the possibility of quitting smoking at this point in time?
Yeah, I've thought about it. But everyone's always telling me to quit, and I've tried before with no luck. It's getting old hearing the same thing over and over again.
I understand that you're tired of hearing the same advice. I'm not here to judge or lecture, but rather to explore your thoughts and feelings about smoking together.
Yeah, yeah, I know people mean well, but it's just not as simple as they make it out to be.
It sounds like quitting smoking has been a challenging journey for you. Can you tell me more about how smoking fits into your life? How long have you been smoking?
I've smoked on and off since I was 14, but it's been consistent for the past 40 years.
That's quite a history with nicotine. It seems like you've tried various methods to quit in the past, but nothing has stuck yet.
Yeah, cold turkey is the only thing that's ever worked for anyone I know, but even then, it's still a struggle.
I hear that you feel it's your choice whether or not to smoke. If there were a situation where you felt compelled to quit, what might that look like?
Hard to say. I've had open-heart surgery and prostate cancer, neither of which made me want to quit.
I understand that this is a personal decision for you. Right now, it seems that smoking is something you see yourself continuing for the foreseeable future.
Yeah, I don't really have any desire to stop at the moment.

Thank you for sharing your thoughts with me today. I appreciate your openness about not wanting to discuss quitting smoking further right now. Would it be okay if we revisit this topic in our next session, perhaps focusing on some of the challenges and benefits related to smoking?
Sure thing, doc. I'm always open to listening.
Great. And remember, wherever you're at with this, we'll work together to find what feels right for you.
Thanks, doc. That means a lot.
It sounds like you're feeling quite frustrated with your weight loss journey, as if you've hit a wall despite all your efforts?
Yes, that's exactly it. I'm putting in so much effort to exercise and eat healthier, but the scale just isn't budging.
I see. So, it feels like no matter how hard you try, you're not seeing the results you'd hoped for?
Exactly. And it's not just that. It feels like no one around me cares or understands what I'm going through.
That must be incredibly isolating. You feel unsupported in this important journey of yours?
Yes, especially by my father. He doesn't seem to understand why I want to lose weight and even thinks I should gain it back.
I see. So, you're feeling misunderstood by your father, as if he doesn't appreciate the importance of your health goals?
Yes, exactly. It's like he thinks I'm trying to change who I am just to fit some ideal, but that's not what this is about for me. I just want to be healthy and feel good about myself.
I understand. You're feeling hurt and misunderstood by your father's reaction, as you believe his perspective doesn't align with your genuine desire for a healthier lifestyle?
Hi, Mary, how was your day?
It's been alright. Where do you need me to sign today?
You can sign right there. I sense that you're not quite in the mood for our chat today.
Not particularly.
I noticed you missed your first class today. That doesn't seem to bother you much?
It's just another day, you know? Why all these questions?
You're wondering why we have these visits and what they're about, aren't you?
Yeah, it feels like an invasion of my privacy.
I understand that it might seem intrusive. Let me explain again what our program is about.
Sure, go ahead.
My role is to ensure you're here and responsive to your GPS, and that we're aware if you leave without permission. It's also a chance for us to get to know each other better.
So you're just checking up on me?
I'm here to support you, Mary. When we first met, you wanted off this program quickly, remember?
Yeah, I guess.
Yet, it seems like you're still feeling annoyed by our visits.
It's just... I don't know if I can promise to stay put.
You're concerned about whether you'll be able to stick to this successfully?
No, it's more like, why does anyone care about my business?
There are many people involved in your life right now, and that can feel overwhelming. It's okay to feel that way.
Yeah, it's just a lot.
You value your freedom greatly, don't you?
More than anything.
What steps do you think could help you regain some of that freedom?
Signing the papers when you come by, I guess.
That's one step. Is there anything else you'd like to share with me before I go today?
Not really.
Okay. I'll be back later today.
Alright, see you then. Bye.
Good afternoon, Mr. Johnson?
Hello.
I'm here to discuss your cholesterol levels and the medication your doctor has prescribed for you.
I've spoken with my doctor about it already. Isn't that his area of expertise?
Indeed, but my role is to support you in understanding how to use this medication effectively and help you maximize its benefits.

Well, truthfully, I'm not entirely sure if I'll start taking the medicine. I know high cholesterol increases my risk of health issues, but this medication can cause muscle weakness, which I simply cannot afford as a truck driver.
Your doctor has explained that uncontrolled cholesterol puts you at significant risk for stroke or heart attack?
Yes, eventually. But right now, it's the potential muscle weakness that concerns me most.

I understand your concern about the present, but let's consider this: the side effect of muscle weakness is quite rare, and the risk of stroke or heart attack is much higher. If you experience any weakness, your doctor can adjust your medication accordingly.
Can't I just take the medicine home and think about it some more?
It's important to start taking it as prescribed, Mr. Johnson. The muscle weakness side effect is rare and not permanent. Your doctor can always make adjustments if needed.
Alright then.

Remember, a stroke or heart attack poses a much greater risk than temporary muscle weakness. Please pick up your medication on your way out and take one pill every day to manage your cholesterol levels effectively.
Understood. I'll do that.
Thank you for your cooperation, Mr. Johnson.
Hello Scott, welcome back.
Hi there.
We had briefly discussed earlier your desire to resume exercising. Can you tell me more about that?
Yeah, I've been meaning to get back into it. I used to work out regularly, but life got busy and now I'm just out of the habit. I feel like I need to restart.
It sounds like you're feeling motivated to make a change. Let's explore this together. Can you help me understand why getting back to the gym is important for you?
Well, I've gained some weight around my middle and I'd like to get back into my old jeans. But more than that, I just feel better when I'm active.

It seems your goal is multifaceted - improving your physical appearance and also enhancing your overall well-being. Let's break this down further. Can you list some reasons why returning to the gym is important for you?
Sure thing.
Great. And let's also brainstorm some strategies that could help you get there consistently. Your gym is only a couple of miles away, right? Have you considered walking or biking there?
That's an idea. But I'd still like to do weightlifting and other exercises at the gym.
Absolutely, variety in your workout routine is important. So, what specific aspects of your appearance would you like to improve through exercise?
I'd just like to fit into my clothes comfortably again and feel healthier overall.
That's a great goal. Now, let's discuss how you can make time for this. What might be some obstacles and potential solutions?
Well, I could wake up an hour earlier to go before work.

That's a practical suggestion. It shows you're committed to making this change. Let's try that out and see how it goes. Between now and our next session, experiment with waking up early and make note of any challenges or successes you encounter. We'll discuss further then.
Okay, I will.
Looking forward to hearing about your progress. Until next time, Scott.
Thanks, bye.
Could you tell me what you understand about the flu shot?
Well, I know the flu can be serious, but since I'm generally healthy, I don't think I really need it. Isn't it more for older people?
It sounds like you believe the vaccine is mainly for those who are vulnerable to illness.
Yeah.
Would you be open to learning more about the flu vaccine and its importance?
Sure, go ahead.

You're correct that being young and healthy means you'd likely fare well with the flu. However, we know that it can be severe for the elderly, pregnant individuals, and babies. By getting vaccinated, you help protect not just yourself but also those around you who might be more susceptible.
I see.
Now that you have this information, how do you feel about receiving the flu vaccine?
My grandparents wouldn't handle the flu well, and my co-worker is pregnant too. It's for their sake that I should get it.
So, considering those in your life who are vulnerable, getting the flu shot could help protect them.
Yes, you're right.
Good afternoon, Dr. Martin. I understand you have a question for me today. Could you tell me what's on your mind?
I apologize if this is confusing, but are you the pharmacist? I had a specific question about my medication, citalopram.

Yes, indeed I am the pharmacist here today. You're taking citalopram, an antidepressant available in 10mg, 20mg, and 40mg strengths. It's primarily excreted through urine with a half-life of approximately 35 hours. Like many medications, it can have side effects affecting various systems, including sexual function, cardiovascular health, and gastrointestinal tract.
Thank you for that information. My main concern was whether citalopram interacts with another medication I'm taking, phenelzine?
Ah, I see. Let me just confirm that for you. Yes, it appears there should be no significant interaction between those two medications at this time.
That's reassuring to hear. Unfortunately, I have another appointment I must attend now.
Of course, Dr. Martin. Please don't hesitate to reach out if you have any other questions or concerns in the future. Take care.
So Tom, this infection has been quite painful for you. We have antibiotics that can help if taken faithfully for 10 days. Are you willing to commit to that?
Absolutely.
I'd like to discuss a screening form you filled out earlier regarding drug use. Is that alright with you?
Sure thing.
Let's review it together. It mentions occasional use of drugs other than medical purposes. Which substances have you been using, Tom?
Methamphetamine, mostly.
I see. And how do you typically consume it?
Snorted, always snort it.
Not injected? And are there any other drugs you use regularly?
Just alcohol, sometimes.
How often would you say you're using methamphetamine?
Two to three times a month, tops.

So occasional use then. As you may know, methamphetamine use carries certain health risks. Given your usage pattern, we consider you a risky user. One potential consequence is sexually transmitted diseases. Do you think your recent STD could be linked to your methamphetamine use?
Yeah, it's possible. I mean, I don't usually have unprotected sex, but when I'm high on meth...
So methamphetamine might cloud your judgment during sexual encounters?
Yeah, that's true.
Apart from this STD scare, how else is methamphetamine affecting your life?
Not really. I mean, I only use it socially with friends at clubs, a couple times a month max.
Tom, given the risks involved, I strongly recommend stopping methamphetamine use altogether.
I understand, but that's easier said than done. It's such a big part of my social life and sex life...
I hear you. On a scale of 0 to 10, how ready are you to quit methamphetamine completely?
Uh, maybe a 3? This STD scare has really shaken me up, but it's still tough to think about quitting cold turkey.
What other concerns do you have regarding your methamphetamine use?
I worry about what it might be cut with. You never know if it's safe or not.
It sounds like you have several reasons for wanting to stop using methamphetamine, despite the challenges involved.
Yeah, I just don't want to end up with something worse than gonorrhea.
What do you think could help make quitting easier?
Having other things to do on weekends, finding a new social circle maybe...
Is there anyone in your life who doesn't use methamphetamine? Someone who might support you through this?
My sister. We're close, and I think she knows about my usage.
Have you talked to her about it?
Not really, but I could. She'd probably be supportive.
So, you see both the benefits and challenges of quitting methamphetamine. It's ultimately your decision, but talking to your sister for support might help.
Yeah, that makes sense.
Let's schedule another appointment in a month then. Would that work for you?
Yes, that'd be fine.

Alright, Chris. I wanted to touch base because we have a strict no-drugs and alcohol policy here at the school. As athletic director, it's my duty to ensure all our student-athletes adhere to this rule. I've heard some whispers about a recent party where you were present, but I don't have concrete evidence yet.

Right. Actually, there's something I'd like to discuss about that weekend. Typically, I'm an honor student who spends weekends studying, and my parents don't allow me to attend parties. However, this time, I felt pressured by friends to go, and once there, I felt compelled to fit in with the drinking games and such.
I see. It's easy to feel that pressure in situations like that. I've been where you are too, Chris. We all want to fit in sometimes.
Exactly. But now, I realize it's not worth compromising my health or my place on the team for temporary social acceptance.
That's a mature perspective, Chris. You understand the consequences better than most. Let's find a way to navigate these situations without compromising your values and our school rules.
I appreciate that. I think I'll avoid those kinds of parties in the future and be more selective about who I spend time with. I don't want my actions to end up online for everyone to see.
That's a smart approach. We need to trust each other here, Chris. If you promise me you'll stick to our rules, we can continue supporting your athletic journey.
I understand and I promise. No more parties or public displays of anything against the rules.
Great. Let's shake on it.
Shake. See you later.
Alright, Chris. Take care.
Good afternoon, Mr. Stowe. I'm Bruce Berger, your case manager with the health plan.
Nice to meet you.
How are you feeling today? I understand you're here to discuss managing your diabetes diagnosis.

It's been a lot to take in. Just found out I have diabetes, and the doctor said my blood sugar was really high. She mentioned all these complications like eye problems and circulation issues. It's scary, and then she told me I need to do all this stuff to manage it. I'm feeling pretty overwhelmed right now.
It sounds like you're feeling blindsided by this news, Mr. Stowe. You're scared about the potential consequences of diabetes, and you're also feeling daunted by the changes you'll need to make.
Yeah, that's it exactly. I don't want those things to happen to me, but when she listed everything I have to do, I thought, "I'm not sure I can handle all that."

Let's break this down into manageable steps, Mr. Stowe. Your doctor is right; we need to get your blood sugar under control to prevent those complications. But we don't have to tackle everything at once. Let's start with what you feel most confident about.
I think taking my medicine as prescribed will be okay. I understand how important it is, given my high blood sugar levels.

That's great to hear. Taking your medication once a day seems doable for now. We can build on that success and gradually incorporate other changes like healthier eating habits and increased physical activity.
The doctor also mentioned monitoring my blood sugar. It seemed complicated at first, but I get it now â€“ it's to track how well the other changes are working.
Exactly. Monitoring gives you feedback so you can see the impact of your efforts on your blood sugar levels. How does this approach make you feel now?
It feels more manageable knowing we're taking things step by step. I'm committed to starting with my medication, and I think I can do that without any issues.
That's wonderful to hear, Mr. Stowe. Let's continue working together like this, focusing on one thing at a time.
Hello, are you Julie Thompson?
Yes, that's me.

Hi Julie, I'm Bruce Berger. I work at the clinic and noticed Sarah's rescue inhaler prescription is ready for pickup. It seems she's been to the ER five times this year due to her asthma. How has that been for you?
It's been really tough. Seeing her struggle to breathe like that... I'm always worried when we have to go to the ER.
It sounds like you're very committed to helping Sarah manage her asthma better.
Absolutely, I'll do anything to prevent those scary episodes.
I also noticed it's been a few months since you last picked up her chronic inhaler prescription. Have you been having trouble with that?
Yes, I found out there are steroids in it, and I don't want Sarah taking them. I've read about the potential side effects... I just don't want her exposed to them.
I understand your concern. You're a caring parent who wants the best for Sarah.
And another thing, I smoke, but I make sure not to around her so it doesn't affect her asthma.
Thank you for being open about that. It shows you're really thinking about Sarah's health.
Let's discuss the chronic inhaler and the steroids you're worried about. This medicine isn't like the ones you've heard about, like anabolic steroids. Can we talk about it?
Sure, I'd like to understand better.

The medicine in her inhaler is a small amount from the same family as those big steroids but doesn't have the same effects. It actually reduces inflammation in Sarah's lungs and isn't absorbed into her body.
Oh, I see. So it won't cause those health problems?
